texts.definition: Gameplay where responsibility for different types of game actions can be divided between participants.
markups: <style="Definition">Gameplay where responsibility for different types of game actions can be divided between participants.</style>

Games where not all actions can be done by one game entity have <style="CurrentLink">Functional Roles</style> - a division of who can do what according to their functional capabilities. These <style="CurrentLink">Functional Roles</style> can be present from the beginning of game instances or develop over time, and can be voluntary or forced upon players.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Sports">Sports</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ice%20Hockey">Ice Hockey</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Soccer">Soccer</link></style> have <style="CurrentLink">Functional Roles</style> defined both by rules - goalies - and by tactics, e.g. forwards and defense players.

Class-based <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> provide different sets of abilities for each class and thereby have <style="CurrentLink">Functional Roles</style>. This has carried over to computer-based version such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20series">Dragon Age</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Neverwinter%20Nights%20series">Neverwinter Nights series</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style>. Similarly, class-based <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:FPS%20Games">First-Person Shooters</link></style> such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlefield%20series">Battlefield</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Team%20Fortress%20series">Team Fortress series</link></style> force teams into various classes so all needed <style="CurrentLink">Functional Roles</style> are filled; the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:FPS%20Games">First-Person Shooter</link></style> in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style> accomplishes <style="CurrentLink">Functional Roles</style> by only letting players have one type of main weapon so the four-player teams need to diversify themselves to have a good mix of firepower.

Supporting Functional Roles requires both that entities can or need to specialize into different roles, and that several entities exist to fill these roles. In practice this means making entities have different Competence Areas and having to engage in Cooperation. Privileged Abilities is the simplest solution to provide different Competence Areas but these can also emerge organically through games that have provide New or Improved Abilities during gameplay. Privileged Abilities can also enforce Cooperation but Teams is another options. Beyond that, specific ways of allowing Competence Areas include Sidegrades, Skills, Tools, and Weapons while Equipment Slots can force specialization since each entity cannot carry Tools or Weapons for each situation (the Left 4 Dead series is an example where Equipment Slots has this consequence). Crossmedia Gameplay in Multiplayer Games can force players to specialize into different roles simply because they have access to different gameplay devices or mediums. Similarly, Asynchronous Collaborative Actions can force players to specialize into different roles based on when they need to play.

<style="CurrentLink">Functional Roles</style> are typically split between players and in this fashion motivates the existence of for example <style="Link"><link="parties">Parties</link></style>, but this can be complemented by use of <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> and the pattern can be used in <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style> if the player has control over many <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>. Beyond all other ways of supporting <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Coordination">Coordination</link></style> that exist, one way appropriate in conjunction with <style="CurrentLink">Functional Roles</style> is to let players distinguish themselves with <style="Link"><link="cosmetic-game-items">Cosmetic Game Items</link></style> according to their roles.

<style="Link"><link="role-selection">Role Selection</link></style> is a typical consequence <style="CurrentLink">Functional Roles</style> and besides the gameplay possibilities offered by <style="CurrentLink">Functional Roles</style>, they typically also give or suggest <style="Link"><link="social-roles">Social Roles</link></style>. Novice players can ease into a game when <style="CurrentLink">Functional Roles</style> require different levels of expertise in <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style>, so the pattern can support <style="Link"><link="actor-detachment">Actor Detachment</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Smooth%20Learning%20Curves">Smooth Learning Curves</link></style> in these types of games; an example of this is playing engineers or medics in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Team%20Fortress%202">Team Fortress 2</link></style>. The pattern can create <style="Link"><link="tiered-participation">Tiered Participation</link></style> when the requirements on engagement in the gameplay differs considerably between the different roles.

In <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Functional Roles</style> let players have <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style> and thereby provides <style="Link"><link="replayability">Replayability</link></style> in that players can have different gameplay experiences by testing different roles. When number of players that can have specific roles are limited, this can lead to <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style> between the players - especially in games with persistent social organizations such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Guilds">Guilds</link></style>. These <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalries</link></style> can in turn lead to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Role%20Reversal">Role Reversals</link></style> during gameplay.
